item.title: Pope: ‘I was thinking of retiring, but instead I surrendered to God’
item.description:
Aboard the papal plane returning to Rome from Lebanon, Pope Leo XIV speaks to journalists about the role of the Holy See, which works “behind-the-scenes” in peace negotiations, so that all parties may lay down arms. Regarding Ukraine, the Pope underlines Europe’s involvement and the important role Italy could play, and answers a question about how he reacted to his election, stressing the importance of giving one’s life to God and letting him "lead the way".

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Aboard the papal plane returning to Rome from Lebanon, Pope Leo XIV speaks to journalists about the role of the Holy See, which works “behind-the-scenes” in peace negotiations, so that all parties may lay down arms. Regarding Ukraine, the Pope underlines Europe’s involvement and the important role Italy could play, and answers a question about how he reacted to his election, stressing the importance of giving one’s life to God and letting him "lead the way".
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/pope-leo-xiv-inflight-press-conference-turkiye-lebanon.html)

item.title: Former teacher Kelly was 'one cog in machine of abuse'

item.title: Italian fashion group Prada buys rival Versace
item.description: The Prada Group closed the purchase of Milan fashion rival Versace in a $1.375 billion US ($1.93 billion Cdn) cash deal that puts the fashion house known for its sexy silhouettes under the same roof as Prada's "ugly chic" aesthetic and Miu Miu's youth-driven appeal.
item.source:markdown:
![People walk by a fashion boutique with three arched windows and the word Prada above each](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/bfa779c9-d06b-4ff5-abb7-4c0034eb083e,1764702111543/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C287%2C5500%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The Prada Group closed the purchase of Milan fashion rival Versace in a $1.375 billion US ($1.93 billion Cdn) cash deal that puts the fashion house known for its sexy silhouettes under the same roof as Prada's "ugly chic" aesthetic and Miu Miu's youth-driven appeal.

item.title: Supt contacted garda about road traffic case, court told
item.description: A garda accused of perverting the course of justice by intervening in potential road traffic prosecutions told investigating officers from the Garda National Bureau of Criminal Investigation that he was contacted by a superintendent about a road traffic case, Limerick Circuit Court has heard.

item.title: 12 officers would have faced misconduct over Hillsborough

item.title: Ex-Honduran president, convicted of trafficking 360 tonnes of cocaine, out of prison after Trump pardon
item.description: Former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, sentenced last year to 45 years in prison for his role in a drug-trafficking operation that moved hundreds of tonnes of cocaine to the United States, was released from prison following a pardon from President Donald Trump, officials confirmed Tuesday.
item.source:markdown:
![A man wearing sunglasses and a mask over his face is shown with hands clasped in front of him and surrounded by several people, including police officers.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/96e93b27-a152-4157-b198-239cb9cff864,1764697373102/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C5760%2C3240%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, sentenced last year to 45 years in prison for his role in a drug-trafficking operation that moved hundreds of tonnes of cocaine to the United States, was released from prison following a pardon from President Donald Trump, officials confirmed Tuesday.

item.title: Asia: Lives upended by cyclones, ‘extreme’ rainfall on the rise, warn UN agencies
item.description: Across southeast Asia, record-breaking rains and flooding caused by back-to-back tropical storms have claimed hundreds of lives and brought devastation and displacement upon entire communities, UN agencies said on Tuesday.

item.title: Pope Leo at Beirut farewell: 'Choose peace as a way, not just a goal'
item.description:
Before taking off for Rome at Beirut’s airport, Pope Leo XIV concludes his Apostolic Journey to Türkiye and Lebanon, calling for dialogue, fraternity, and reconciliation across the Middle East and expressing his hope that those who “currently consider themselves enemies” may embrace a spirit of fraternity and commitment to peace.

item.title: Man guilty of helping move Keane Mulready-Woods remains

item.title: Why does Trump keep berating female reporters?
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's recent remarks towards female journalists, including calling one 'piggy,' is renewing discussion about how much journalists are expected to tolerate as they do their jobs. Industry experts suggest these incidents are 'an unmistakable pattern of hostility — often directed at women — that undermines the essential role of a free and independent press.'
item.source:markdown:
![US President Donald Trump berating female reporters. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/ca4728b4-ee65-4dc0-adb8-2f5ccedb3d23,1764550304383/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C66%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
U.S. President Donald Trump's recent remarks towards female journalists, including calling one 'piggy,' is renewing discussion about how much journalists are expected to tolerate as they do their jobs. Industry experts suggest these incidents are 'an unmistakable pattern of hostility — often directed at women — that undermines the essential role of a free and independent press.'

item.title: ‘Every step a struggle:’ Nigerian woman with disabilities leads push for dignity and inclusion
item.description: A woman living with disabilities in a camp for displaced people in Nigeria is demonstrating why it is essential that people like her are included in society and how dignity can be protected even in the harshest places.
item.source:markdown: A woman living with disabilities in a camp for displaced people in Nigeria is demonstrating why it is essential that people like her are included in society and how dignity can be protected even in the harshest places.

item.title: Record cocaine seizure in Haitian waters underlines country’s ‘pivotal’ trafficking role
item.description: A record seizure of cocaine off the coast of Haiti has underlined the island nation’s “pivotal role in trafficking routes linking South America, the Caribbean and the United States of America,” according to the United Nations.
item.source:markdown: A record seizure of cocaine off the coast of Haiti has underlined the island nation’s “pivotal role in trafficking routes linking South America, the Caribbean and the United States of America,” according to the United Nations.

item.title: Cyclone Ditwah brings worst flooding in decades to Sri Lanka, killing hundreds
item.description: Sri Lanka is facing one of its worst flood disasters in two decades, with nearly one million people affected and more than 400 reported dead or missing after Cyclone Ditwah unleashed catastrophic flooding and landslides across the island.
item.source:markdown: Sri Lanka is facing one of its worst flood disasters in two decades, with nearly one million people affected and more than 400 reported dead or missing after Cyclone Ditwah unleashed catastrophic flooding and landslides across the island.

item.description: A meeting between US and Ukrainian officials in Florida was "very productive", US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said, adding that work still remains towards ending Russia's war in Ukraine.

item.title: Tropical storm deaths top 600 in Southeast Asia
item.description: The death toll mounted to over 600 from floods and landslides caused by torrential rains across three countries in Southeast Asia, officials said, as relief efforts for tens of thousands of displaced people continued over the weekend.
item.source:markdown: The death toll mounted to over 600 from floods and landslides caused by torrential rains across three countries in Southeast Asia, officials said, as relief efforts for tens of thousands of displaced people continued over the weekend.

item.title: German Christmas markets open 1 year after deadly attack
item.description: Christmas markets are open in Germany with increased security this year. In 2024, a man drove an SUV into crowds at the Christmas market in the central city of Magdeburg, killing six. Freelance journalist Natalie Carney spoke to visitors at the Christmas market in Munich.
item.source:markdown:
![German Christmas markets open 1 year after deadly attack.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/d48bfc08-2853-4261-a99e-893b7a8ab6d5,1764369428037/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Christmas markets are open in Germany with increased security this year. In 2024, a man drove an SUV into crowds at the Christmas market in the central city of Magdeburg, killing six. Freelance journalist Natalie Carney spoke to visitors at the Christmas market in Munich.

item.title: Netanyahu submits request for a pardon during his ongoing corruption trial
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday asked the country’s president to grant him a pardon from corruption charges — seeking to end a long-running trial that has bitterly divided the nation.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday asked the country’s president to grant him a pardon from corruption charges — seeking to end a long-running trial that has bitterly divided the nation.

item.title: Indonesian residents hunt for food and water after deadly floods; 193 dead in Sri Lanka
item.description: Some residents of the flood-hit Indonesian island of Sumatra have resorted to stealing food and water to survive, authorities said Sunday, while Sri Lankan officials said deaths from floods and mudslides in that island nation have risen to 193.
item.source:markdown:
![People float in a zodiaz boat in flooded waters with palm trees along the shoreline.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/203465e3-8eb1-4c2c-aa9e-1af3358a628f,1764507767526/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C18%2C3411%2C1918%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Some residents of the flood-hit Indonesian island of Sumatra have resorted to stealing food and water to survive, authorities said Sunday, while Sri Lankan officials said deaths from floods and mudslides in that island nation have risen to 193.

item.title: Death toll in Hong Kong apartment complex blaze rises to 146 as the city mourns
item.description: The death toll in Hong Kong’s apartment complex  blaze rose to 146 on Sunday as investigators discovered more bodies in the burned-out buildings. A steady stream of people placed bouquets of flowers at an ever-growing makeshift memorial at the scene of the disaster, among the worst in the city’s history.
item.source:markdown:
![People kneel to deposit flowers with two towers covered in burnt scaffolding in the background.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/ad5cf993-a0c2-43f5-a317-2fb9a71f59e5,1764506670495/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C361%2C4500%2C2531%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The death toll in Hong Kong’s apartment complex blaze rose to 146 on Sunday as investigators discovered more bodies in the burned-out buildings. A steady stream of people placed bouquets of flowers at an ever-growing makeshift memorial at the scene of the disaster, among the worst in the city’s history.

item.title: How significant was an EU ruling on same-sex marriage?

item.title: Should kidfluencers be banned? That’s the plan in the EU
item.description: With the top kidfluencers in the world earning millions a year, leaders in the EU are worried the lure of lucrative sponsorship deals may tempt some parents to expliot their children in sponsored posts online. So this week, the EU announced plans to ban social media platforms from providing financial or material incentives for kidfluencing. Experts says Canada needs to come up with its own law.
item.source:markdown:
![A girl with blonde hair and a smaller girl with brown hair look at a table full of toy boxes for the line Millie and Friends Mouse in the House. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/69c4ee08-eb65-4b47-a46b-10d3113be42f,1764300156200/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C5%2C2361%2C1328%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
With the top kidfluencers in the world earning millions a year, leaders in the EU are worried the lure of lucrative sponsorship deals may tempt some parents to expliot their children in sponsored posts online. So this week, the EU announced plans to ban social media platforms from providing financial or material incentives for kidfluencing. Experts says Canada needs to come up with its own law.

item.title: Trump sent federal troops to 'save' Chicago. The 'Midway Blitz' raids forced the Windy City to defend itself
item.description: After the death of MAGA activist Charlie Kirk, U.S. President Donald Trump promised "to save Chicago" from crime and migrants. But in the wake of violent immigration raids, Chicagoans themselves are divided over who the criminals are — and who is ultimately responsible for keeping their city safe.
item.source:markdown:
![Demonstrators face off against rows of federal immigration enforcement agents.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b0caa8fa-b7f5-437a-ba4f-d364e5e0c314,1764351415388/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C310%2C5961%2C3353%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
After the death of MAGA activist Charlie Kirk, U.S. President Donald Trump promised "to save Chicago" from crime and migrants. But in the wake of violent immigration raids, Chicagoans themselves are divided over who the criminals are — and who is ultimately responsible for keeping their city safe.

item.title: American ALS patient died alone after paying $84K US in pursuit of healing at controversial Sask. facility
item.description: A 70-year-old American ALS patient came to Saskatchewan chasing the promise of healing offered by the Dr. Goodenowe Restorative Health Center in Moose Jaw, Sask. But former Goodenowe employees say that as her condition worsened, Goodenowe centre management left Susie to fight for her life on her own.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a hospital bed with an oxygen tube.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/51795ab6-e1ed-4ae5-93d5-039254fd4ec0,1762282146669/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A 70-year-old American ALS patient came to Saskatchewan chasing the promise of healing offered by the Dr. Goodenowe Restorative Health Center in Moose Jaw, Sask. But former Goodenowe employees say that as her condition worsened, Goodenowe centre management left Susie to fight for her life on her own.

item.title: Maduro slams 'colonial threat' as Trump says Venezuelan airspace should be closed
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump on Saturday said that the airspace "above and surrounding" Venezuela should be considered as "closed in its entirety," an assertion that raised more questions about the U.S. pressure on Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro. His government accused Trump of making a "colonial threat" and seeking to undermine the South American country's sovereignty.
item.source:markdown:
![Venezuela President Nicolás Maduro and U.S. President Donald Trump](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4a0461b0-810a-4010-a589-6d5b23e307ab,1764439599470/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C53%2C1270%2C714%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
U.S. President Donald Trump on Saturday said that the airspace "above and surrounding" Venezuela should be considered as "closed in its entirety," an assertion that raised more questions about the U.S. pressure on Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro. His government accused Trump of making a "colonial threat" and seeking to undermine the South American country's sovereignty.

item.title: Airlines work to fix software glitch on A320 aircraft, causing short-term flight disruptions
item.description: Airlines around the world reported short-term disruptions heading into the weekend as they fixed software on a widely used commercial aircraft, after an analysis found the computer code may have contributed to a sudden drop in the altitude of a JetBlue plane last month.
item.source:markdown:
![Two planes on a runway. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/42744eac-396e-4882-8542-feacea1a1164,1764430621401/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28303%2C438%2C5061%2C2846%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Airlines around the world reported short-term disruptions heading into the weekend as they fixed software on a widely used commercial aircraft, after an analysis found the computer code may have contributed to a sudden drop in the altitude of a JetBlue plane last month.

item.title: The Miss Universe drama somehow got worse. Is this the pageant's breaking point?

item.title: Prices of many tractors double amid material costs rise
item.description: The value of farm machinery to the Irish economy has reached €4.76 billion, according to the first ever economic report in the area, while a jump in raw material costs has contributed to the prices of many tractors doubling in the last decade.

item.title: 33 dead, thousands displaced as record rains hit Thailand
item.description: Authorities in Thailand plan to send helicopters to evacuate critically ill patients from a southern hospital marooned by some of the region's worst floods in years, as the death toll rose to 33, with more rain expected.
item.source:markdown: Authorities in Thailand plan to send helicopters to evacuate critically ill patients from a southern hospital marooned by some of the region's worst floods in years, as the death toll rose to 33, with more rain expected.

item.title: Woman jailed for life for New Zealand 'suitcase murders'
item.description: A South Korean-born New Zealand woman has been sentenced to life in prison for murdering her two young children, whose bodies were discovered in suitcases in an abandoned storage locker more than three years ago, New Zealand media reported.
item.source:markdown: A South Korean-born New Zealand woman has been sentenced to life in prison for murdering her two young children, whose bodies were discovered in suitcases in an abandoned storage locker more than three years ago, New Zealand media reported.

item.title: Hong Kong highrise fire leaves at least 36 dead

item.title: F-35 beat Gripen fighter jet 'by a mile' in 2021 Defence Department competition
item.description: The American-built F-35 fighter jet dominated its Swedish rival Gripen in terms of technical and military capabilities during a competition held by the Defence Department in 2021, according to data obtained by Radio-Canada.

item.title: Trump changes Ukraine deal deadline, envoy to meet Putin

item.title: Government 'budgeting like there's no tomorrow' - Ifac

item.title: France arrests two men, two women over Louvre robbery

item.source:markdown: French authorities have arrested four more people in the probe into last month's spectacular daylight theft of imperial jewels from the Louvre museum, the top Paris prosecutor has said.

item.title: HP to cut thousands of jobs due to AI adoption

item.title: Murphy's office asks SF to remove social media photo

item.title: Pope: In Nicaea a message of unity for Christians, in Lebanon for peace
item.description:
At Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo XIV answers journalists’ questions outside Villa Barberini. He describes his upcoming apostolic journey to Türkiye and Lebanon as a trip marked by hope and peace. On Ukraine and the Middle East, he urges always seeking dialogue to end war. Regarding efforts to stop violence against women on the day dedicated to the issue, he says that mentalities must change beginning with the education of young people.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
At Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo XIV answers journalists’ questions outside Villa Barberini. He describes his upcoming apostolic journey to Türkiye and Lebanon as a trip marked by hope and peace. On Ukraine and the Middle East, he urges always seeking dialogue to end war. Regarding efforts to stop violence against women on the day dedicated to the issue, he says that mentalities must change beginning with the education of young people.

item.title: Voice of peace and hope: Pope Leo's visit to Türkiye and Lebanon
item.description:
The director of the Holy See Press Office presents Pope Leo XIV’s first apostolic journey that takes him to Türkiye and Lebanon, emphasising ecumenical commemoration, interreligious dialogue, and support for local Christian communities. item.title: Nigeria: Hundreds abducted in the north as insurgent attacks rise
item.description: Authorities in Nigeria are being urged to investigate the wave of abductions in the West African country, where attacks by insurgent groups are increasing.
item.source:markdown: Authorities in Nigeria are being urged to investigate the wave of abductions in the West African country, where attacks by insurgent groups are increasing.

item.title: Why a woman is killed every 10 minutes; the rising wave of global femicide
item.description: Every 10 minutes, partners and family members killed a woman intentionally in 2024 and that trend is growing, according to the UN.
item.source:markdown: Every 10 minutes, partners and family members killed a woman intentionally in 2024 and that trend is growing, according to the UN.

item.title: Global HIV response facing worst setback in decades, UNAIDS warns
item.description: The global response to HIV is facing its most serious setback in decades, UNAIDS warned on Tuesday, as abrupt funding cuts and a deteriorating human rights environment disrupt prevention and treatment services across dozens of countries.
item.source:markdown: The global response to HIV is facing its most serious setback in decades, UNAIDS warned on Tuesday, as abrupt funding cuts and a deteriorating human rights environment disrupt prevention and treatment services across dozens of countries.

item.title: Over 600 million children exposed to violence at home, UNICEF warns
item.description: More than one in four children globally – around 610 million – live with mothers who have experienced physical, emotional or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in the past year, making violence a part of their everyday lives, according to new data released by the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: More than one in four children globally – around 610 million – live with mothers who have experienced physical, emotional or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in the past year, making violence a part of their everyday lives, according to new data released by the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on Tuesday.

item.title: On International Day of Solidarity, UN urges greater support and aid for Palestinians
item.description: For over two years, tens of thousands of people have been killed in Gaza. The enclave faces its most severe economic collapse in history, and even amid a fragile ceasefire, children continue to die.
item.source:markdown: For over two years, tens of thousands of people have been killed in Gaza. The enclave faces its most severe economic collapse in history, and even amid a fragile ceasefire, children continue to die.

item.title: Majority of crimes last year committed by re-offenders
item.description: Four of every five thefts, frauds, robberies and deception offences solved last year were committed by or involved an offender with a prior criminal history.
item.source:markdown: Four of every five thefts, frauds, robberies and deception offences solved last year were committed by or involved an offender with a prior criminal history.

item.title: Adjournment in dangerous driving case where child died
item.description: Lawyers for a doctor accused of dangerous driving causing his six-year-old daughter's death in the Midlands last year have asked for one final adjournment before he enters a plea.
item.source:markdown: Lawyers for a doctor accused of dangerous driving causing his six-year-old daughter's death in the Midlands last year have asked for one final adjournment before he enters a plea.

item.title: Harris to ensure 'ongoing careful management' of finances
item.description: The Tánaiste and Minister for Finance has said he will ensure that there is "ongoing careful management of the public finances" in his new role.
item.source:markdown: The Tánaiste and Minister for Finance has said he will ensure that there is "ongoing careful management of the public finances" in his new role.

item.title: Ukraine dials down US peace plan but core issues remain
item.description: After last week's US ultimatum to accept an unfavourable peace deal, Ukrainian officials have strengthened Kyiv's hand after intense discussions with US officials in Geneva last Sunday. But the core issues of territory, NATO membership and security guarantees remain undecided
item.source:markdown: After last week's US ultimatum to accept an unfavourable peace deal, Ukrainian officials have strengthened Kyiv's hand after intense discussions with US officials in Geneva last Sunday. But the core issues of territory, NATO membership and security guarantees remain undecided

item.title: Same-sex marriage should be recognised in bloc - EU court
item.description: The EU's highest court has ruled that same-sex marriages must be respected throughout the bloc and rebuked Poland for refusing to recognise a marriage between two of its citizens that took place in Germany.
item.source:markdown: The EU's highest court has ruled that same-sex marriages must be respected throughout the bloc and rebuked Poland for refusing to recognise a marriage between two of its citizens that took place in Germany.

item.title: Graham Linehan cleared of harassing transgender activist
item.description: Father Ted co-creator Graham Linehan has been found guilty of the criminal damage of a transgender woman's phone at an event in London last year, but not guilty of harassment.
item.source:markdown: Father Ted co-creator Graham Linehan has been found guilty of the criminal damage of a transgender woman's phone at an event in London last year, but not guilty of harassment.

item.title: Doctrine of the Faith: Monogamy is not a limitation but a promise of the infinite
item.description:
The doctrinal Note Una caro. In Praise of Monogamy has been published, exploring the value of marriage as an “exclusive union and mutual belonging.” It highlights the importance of conjugal charity and attentiveness to the poor, and condemns all forms of violence, both physical and psychological. In an individualistic and consumerist age, young people must be educated to understand love as responsibility and trust in the other.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The doctrinal Note Una caro. In Praise of Monogamy has been published, exploring the value of marriage as an “exclusive union and mutual belonging.” It highlights the importance of conjugal charity and attentiveness to the poor, and condemns all forms of violence, both physical and psychological. In an individualistic and consumerist age, young people must be educated to understand love as responsibility and trust in the other.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-11/doctrine-of-faith-monogamy-not-limitation-but-promise-infinite.html)

item.title: Legal challenge to MetroLink to cause 'inevitable delay'
item.description: A judicial review of the planned MetroLink rail line for Dublin will result in an "inevitable delay" to the project, Transport Infrastructure Ireland has said, adding that it hopes that the matter will progress efficiently through the courts.
item.source:markdown: A judicial review of the planned MetroLink rail line for Dublin will result in an "inevitable delay" to the project, Transport Infrastructure Ireland has said, adding that it hopes that the matter will progress efficiently through the courts.

item.title: Sudanese army, paramilitary fighters haven't signed onto truce plan, Trump adviser says
item.description: The United States has presented Sudan's warring parties with a proposal for a truce but neither side has formally accepted it, U.S. envoy Massad Boulos said Tuesday, as the army accused its rivals of staging an attack despite declaring a ceasefire.

The United States has presented Sudan's warring parties with a proposal for a truce but neither side has formally accepted it, U.S. envoy Massad Boulos said Tuesday, as the army accused its rivals of staging an attack despite declaring a ceasefire.

item.title: Court order prevents L.A. coroner from releasing details of teen's body found in singer d4vd's Tesla
item.description: Los Angeles police have blocked the county coroner's office from releasing details about the death of a teen girl whose body was found in the trunk of a car registered to the singer d4vd, the medical examiner's office said on Monday.

item.title: Russian attacks kill at least 7 in Ukraine, as flurry of talks on peace plan proceed
item.description: Russia launched a wave of attacks on Ukraine on Tuesday, killing at least seven people in overnight strikes that hit city buildings and energy infrastructure, while a Ukrainian attack in southern Russia killed three people and damaged homes, authorities said. Meanwhile talks aimed at putting a halt to the hostilities were taking place in Europe and Abu Dhabi.

item.title: Some wins for multilateralism at the G20 — and big questions about its long-term future
item.description: The G20 summit is supposed to be the pinnacle of multilateralism: the idea that nations can co-operate, compromise and co-ordinate for the greater good. But a lot has changed in the past two decades.

item.title: Hawaii's Kilauea volcano produces dome fountain of lava

item.title: Jimmy Cliff, reggae legend, dies aged 81

item.title: Rise in legal advice requests to homelessness law centre

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Spotlight on Gaza, the West Bank and Lebanon
item.description: The Security Council is meeting against the backdrop of Gaza’s fragile ceasefire, with ambassadors expected to urge Israel and Hamas to stick to their commitments amid renewed violence and deepening humanitarian needs. The session is likely to focus on safeguarding the truce, easing aid access restrictions and sustaining political momentum. With tensions also rising in the occupied West Bank and southern Lebanon, the meeting will test whether the Council can help stabilise the situation and keep alive a credible path towards Palestinian self-determination. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. For in-depth meetings coverage, go here.

item.title: €400,000 each for two solicitors defamed by Denis O'Brien
item.description: Two human rights solicitors have been awarded more than €400,000 each in damages after a High Court jury found they were defamed by businessman Denis O'Brien and his spokesman, James Morrissey, almost ten years ago.
item.source:markdown: Two human rights solicitors have been awarded more than €400,000 each in damages after a High Court jury found they were defamed by businessman Denis O'Brien and his spokesman, James Morrissey, almost ten years ago.

item.title: Pope Leo to young people: Technology can help us live our Christian faith
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV meets online with over 15,000 teenagers gathered in Indianapolis, Indiana, and invites young Catholics to grow in friendship with Jesus Christ, use technology healthily to deepen their faith, and avoid using political categories to speak about the Church.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope Leo XIV meets online with over 15,000 teenagers gathered in Indianapolis, Indiana, and invites young Catholics to grow in friendship with Jesus Christ, use technology healthily to deepen their faith, and avoid using political categories to speak about the Church.

item.title: Man jailed for manslaughter of Irish woman in New York
item.description: A man has been sentenced to 24 years in prison for the manslaughter of Irish woman Sarah McNally at a bar in Queens in New York last year.
item.source:markdown: A man has been sentenced to 24 years in prison for the manslaughter of Irish woman Sarah McNally at a bar in Queens in New York last year.

item.title: 'We made the impossible possible,' says Curaçao player heading to World Cup
item.description: The tiny Caribbean country of Curaçao, with a population of slightly less than 160,000, has become the smallest country ever to qualify for the World Cup. Kenji Gorré, one of their players, says making it to soccer's most watched tournament is 'life-changing.'
item.source:markdown:
![A fan holds the flag of Curaçao.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/6e23a882-a319-4c81-b259-5d3e7e94e0cf,1763759644052/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C3096%2C1741%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The tiny Caribbean country of Curaçao, with a population of slightly less than 160,000, has become the smallest country ever to qualify for the World Cup. Kenji Gorré, one of their players, says making it to soccer's most watched tournament is 'life-changing.'

item.title: Kremlin claim on Irish neutrality 'nonsense' - Taoiseach
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has described as "nonsense" a claim from the Kremlin that Ireland is losing its neutrality.

item.title: Peacocks & Payments: Old issues cloud McVerry Trust revamp plans

item.title: ICCL accepts error over letter from European Commission
item.description: The Irish Council of Civil Liberties (ICCL) has accepted that it mistook a letter from the European Commission as pertaining to the appointment of Niamh Sweeney to the Data Protection Commission in September, when it in fact related to a separate ICCL complaint to Brussels.
item.source:markdown: The Irish Council of Civil Liberties (ICCL) has accepted that it mistook a letter from the European Commission as pertaining to the appointment of Niamh Sweeney to the Data Protection Commission in September, when it in fact related to a separate ICCL complaint to Brussels.

item.title: COP30 negotiations at difficult stage, says minister
item.description: Minister for Climate Energy and Environment, Darragh O'Brien, who is attending the COP30 summit at Belem in Brazil has said the climate negotiations have reached a difficult stage.
item.source:markdown: Minister for Climate Energy and Environment, Darragh O'Brien, who is attending the COP30 summit at Belem in Brazil has said the climate negotiations have reached a difficult stage.

item.title: Teenager charged with manslaughter after bus altercation

item.title: CSO report looks at suicide deaths from 2018 to 2022
item.description: 2020 recorded the largest number of female deaths due to suicide in a five-year period between 2018 and 2022, according to figures from the Central Statistics Office.
item.source:markdown: 2020 recorded the largest number of female deaths due to suicide in a five-year period between 2018 and 2022, according to figures from the Central Statistics Office.

item.title: Narwhal carcass found in 'remarkable' Donegal stranding
item.description: An arctic species of whale, normally seen in the waters off Greenland, Canada and Siberia has been recorded in Ireland for the first time, after a carcass was found washed up on a beach in Co Donegal.
item.source:markdown: An arctic species of whale, normally seen in the waters off Greenland, Canada and Siberia has been recorded in Ireland for the first time, after a carcass was found washed up on a beach in Co Donegal.

item.title: Two Italian priests martyred under Nazism in 1944 to be beatified
item.description:
Two young priests killed in Nazi reprisals in Italy's Emilia Romagna region are to be beatified, following decrees promulgated on Friday, which included four new Venerables from Italy, Australia, and Brazil.

Read all

item.title: Can industrial growth and climate action go hand in hand?
item.description: Do higher living standards in developing countries have to mean more polluting, fossil-fuel dependent industries? Or is a low-carbon alternative possible? As the world grapples with climate change, economic inequality, and rapid technological shifts, next week’s Global Industry Summit will tackle these questions, bringing together governments, business leaders, and innovators to shape solutions that balance prosperity with sustainability.
item.source:markdown: Do higher living standards in developing countries have to mean more polluting, fossil-fuel dependent industries? Or is a low-carbon alternative possible? As the world grapples with climate change, economic inequality, and rapid technological shifts, next week’s Global Industry Summit will tackle these questions, bringing together governments, business leaders, and innovators to shape solutions that balance prosperity with sustainability.

item.title: Gaza: Two children killed every day during fragile ceasefire, says UNICEF
item.description: Ongoing attacks and airstrikes attributed to Israeli forces in Gaza continue to kill and maim people of all ages in the shattered enclave despite an agreed ceasefire, UN agencies said on Friday.
item.source:markdown: Ongoing attacks and airstrikes attributed to Israeli forces in Gaza continue to kill and maim people of all ages in the shattered enclave despite an agreed ceasefire, UN agencies said on Friday.

item.title: It’s time for leadership and vision, Guterres tells G20 in South Africa
item.description: A South African flag-coloured King Protea flower – symbolising hope and regeneration – is the chosen logo for this year’s G20 Leaders’ Summit, taking place on African soil for the first time.
item.source:markdown: A South African flag-coloured King Protea flower – symbolising hope and regeneration – is the chosen logo for this year’s G20 Leaders’ Summit, taking place on African soil for the first time.

item.title: UN presents UN80 Initiative Action Plan, setting coordinated path for system-wide reforms
item.description: The United Nations outlined how it intends to advance one of its most comprehensive system-wide reform efforts in decades, as Under-Secretary-General for Policy Guy Ryder presented the UN80 Initiative Action Plan. The plan brings the Secretary-General’s major UN80 reform proposals into a single, coherent structure to streamline efforts that will make the UN system deliver better.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations outlined how it intends to advance one of its most comprehensive system-wide reform efforts in decades, as Under-Secretary-General for Policy Guy Ryder presented the UN80 Initiative Action Plan. The plan brings the Secretary-General’s major UN80 reform proposals into a single, coherent structure to streamline efforts that will make the UN system deliver better.

item.title: UN decries ‘truly horrific’ massacres in DR Congo
item.description: Seventeen civilians, including women in labour and patients receiving care, were slaughtered inside a Catholic Church-run health centre in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) last week.
item.source:markdown: Seventeen civilians, including women in labour and patients receiving care, were slaughtered inside a Catholic Church-run health centre in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) last week.

item.title: From waste pickers to courtrooms: Women demand a gender focus at COP30
item.description: On the scheduled final day of COP30 in Belém, tense negotiations are stretching into Friday afternoon as divisions persist. Amid the ongoing talks, one message is cutting through the noise: there is no climate justice without gender equality.
item.source:markdown: On the scheduled final day of COP30 in Belém, tense negotiations are stretching into Friday afternoon as divisions persist. Amid the ongoing talks, one message is cutting through the noise: there is no climate justice without gender equality.

item.title: Pope Leo consolidates governance reform for Vatican City Commission
item.description:
With a Motu Proprio, Pope Leo XIV has abrogated Article 8 n. 1 of the previous Fundamental Law of Vatican City State, which had allowed only cardinals to serve as president of the Commission, a position currently held by Sister Raffaella Petrini. The Pope, therefore, consolidates a change wanted by Francis and resolves an issue that had emerged due to increasingly “complex and pressing” governance needs.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
With a Motu Proprio, Pope Leo XIV has abrogated Article 8 n. 1 of the previous Fundamental Law of Vatican City State, which had allowed only cardinals to serve as president of the Commission, a position currently held by Sister Raffaella Petrini. The Pope, therefore, consolidates a change wanted by Francis and resolves an issue that had emerged due to increasingly “complex and pressing” governance needs.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-leo-xiv-motu-proprio-presidency-vatican-city-commission.html)

item.title: It would be foolish to underestimate what Trump is capable of, says author Louise Penny
item.description: Louise Penny’s new novel explores a sinister plot to make Canada the 51st state — but she’s keen to point out that she wrote it before Donald Trump was re-elected as U.S. president. She spoke with Matt Galloway live on stage at the Haskell Free Library, right on the U.S.-Canada border.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman and man talk on a stage](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f2056e70-11bd-485c-80ab-41a4b4e23934,1763738454880/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%2863%2C632%2C5672%2C3190%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Louise Penny’s new novel explores a sinister plot to make Canada the 51st state — but she’s keen to point out that she wrote it before Donald Trump was re-elected as U.S. president. She spoke with Matt Galloway live on stage at the Haskell Free Library, right on the U.S.-Canada border.

item.description:

item.title: 60 years of Nostra Aetate: from a seed of hope a great tree has grown
item.description:
Participants from numerous countries and various religious traditions gathered at the international symposium "Nostra Aetate: 60 Years Later" held at the Pontifical University of the Holy Cross in Rome. Cardinal George Koovakad, Prefect of the Dicastery for Interreligious Dialogue and one of the speakers, emphasized that interreligious dialogue must receive greater attention on the international stage and that the spirit of Nostra Aetate remains essential for contemporary peacebuilding efforts.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Zelenskyy says Ukraine may face 'very difficult choice' as U.S. gives deadline on peace plan
item.description: Ukraine may face a hard choice at a pivotal point in its almost four-year fight to defeat Russia's full-scale invasion, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told Ukrainians in a national address Friday, pledging to hold constructive discussions with Washington on a U.S. peace proposal in what he called "truly one of the most difficult moments in our history."
item.source:markdown:
![A bearded man shakes hands in an ornate room with a taller, clean shaven man in suit and tie.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f4be52bc-1077-49e9-a0c6-619f4c83b9f5,1763740641894/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C226%2C3000%2C1687%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Ukraine may face a hard choice at a pivotal point in its almost four-year fight to defeat Russia's full-scale invasion, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told Ukrainians in a national address Friday, pledging to hold constructive discussions with Washington on a U.S. peace proposal in what he called "truly one of the most difficult moments in our history."

item.title: Pilot killed as Indian fighter jet crashes at Dubai Air Show
item.description: An Indian HAL Tejas crashed Friday local time while flying a demonstration flight for a crowd at the Dubai Air Show, sending black smoke over the Maktoum International Airport in the Emirates. It wasn't immediately clear if the pilot ejected the aircraft.
item.source:markdown:
![Fire fighters in uniforms, about four, are shown near a pile of wreckage on dirt ground. Some of them employ hoses to spray on the wreckage.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/0188f7d6-f1a3-4937-b303-742643b4e250,1763727133204/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C2030%2C1141%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.description: Mexico City began a project this week to exhume and identify thousands of bodies from an area of common graves in a municipal cemetery as part of a multi-agency strategy to deal with its growing list of people registered as disappeared.

item.title: Why Canada is winning the travel trade war with the U.S.
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump’s divisive politics, tariffs and heightened border security have helped drive a decline in international tourism spending in the U.S. Meanwhile, polls and industry experts suggest a surge of Canadian patriotism and perceptions of Canada as a safe and friendly destination helped drive a record-breaking summer for tourism in the country.
item.source:markdown:
![Air passengers at airport walk by Canadians flags. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7e09d118-e088-4ce6-a58e-accc2d68ed46,1763588697710/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28512%2C676%2C3798%2C2136%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Talks at WRC over school secretary pensions break down
item.description: Talks at the Workplace Relations Commission aimed at resolving a pensions dispute involving school secretaries and caretakers have broken down. The negotiations ended this evening without agreement, and the workers' trade union, Fórsa, said it wants the matter to be referred to the Labour Court.

item.title: Actor Kevin Spacey says he's living out of hotels after losing Hollywood roles
item.description: Several men accused Spacey of making unwanted sexual advances during the #MeToo movement. item.title: Warner Music and Udio settle lawsuit, agree to build new AI music platform
item.description: The deal settles Warner's copyright infringement claims against AI music generation platform Udio, and will allow the platform to train its AI on licensed and authorized music from its artists. This agreement closely mirrors one signed weeks ago between Udio and Universal Music Group, and comes as AI generated songs and artists have been increasingly popping up on streaming platforms and rising on music charts.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Fleeing the frontline in Ukraine
item.description: The lives of people living in Ukraine on the frontline of the war with Russia are becoming more tenuous and support is being provided for those who want to leave as well as those who want to stay in their homes.
item.source:markdown: The lives of people living in Ukraine on the frontline of the war with Russia are becoming more tenuous and support is being provided for those who want to leave as well as those who want to stay in their homes.

item.title: Civilian deaths in Ukraine surge past last year’s toll as winter deepens crisis, Security Council warned
item.description: Millions in Ukraine have been left without heating, water or basic public services as winter temperatures plunge – and civilian deaths this year have already surpassed the total for 2024, the UN Security Council heard on Thursday.
item.source:markdown: Millions in Ukraine have been left without heating, water or basic public services as winter temperatures plunge – and civilian deaths this year have already surpassed the total for 2024, the UN Security Council heard on Thursday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Violence against Haitian women, WHO alert over support for survivors worldwide, Youth Activist Summit marks hope over hate
item.description: Between January and September, over 7,400 cases of gender-based violence (GBV) were reported in Haiti – an average of about 27 per day, according to UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric.
item.source:markdown: Between January and September, over 7,400 cases of gender-based violence (GBV) were reported in Haiti – an average of about 27 per day, according to UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric.

item.title: ‘The world is watching’: Guterres and Lula urge unity as COP30 talks near deadline
item.description: With the clock ticking on climate negotiations in Belém, UN Secretary-General António Guterres and Brazil’s President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, speaking separately, delivered a united message: the world is watching, and compromise cannot wait.
item.source:markdown: With the clock ticking on climate negotiations in Belém, UN Secretary-General António Guterres and Brazil’s President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, speaking separately, delivered a united message: the world is watching, and compromise cannot wait.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Spotlight on rising casualties in Ukraine
item.description: The Security Council is holding a rare open briefing on Ukraine following days of deadly attacks by Russia on civilian areas and amid a renewed US mission to Kyiv in search of a peace deal. With attacks on energy infrastructure soaring and civilian casualties climbing, Council members have demanded answers and action. Can the Council increase pressure on veto-wielding Moscow, secure better protection and aid for civilians, and push toward an elusive ceasefire? Follow live below, find full UN meetings coverage here; UN News app users can click here.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council is holding a rare open briefing on Ukraine following days of deadly attacks by Russia on civilian areas and amid a renewed US mission to Kyiv in search of a peace deal. Can the Council increase pressure on veto-wielding Moscow, secure better protection and aid for civilians, and push toward an elusive ceasefire? item.title: Security Council’s veto power is ‘poster child’ of global gridlock, says Baerbock
item.description: General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock warned on Thursday that repeated deadlock in the Security Council has become the “poster child” for wider global gridlock, undermining trust in multilateral institutions.
item.source:markdown: General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock warned on Thursday that repeated deadlock in the Security Council has become the “poster child” for wider global gridlock, undermining trust in multilateral institutions.

item.title: What’s at stake in the COP30 negotiations?
item.description: Talks at the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, were suspended on Thursday after a fire broke out in the venue, triggering evacuations that halted negotiations between more than 190 delegations. The summit was set to conclude Friday, and the disruption came at a critical moment as countries were locked in tense debates over fossil fuels and climate finance. The outcome of these talks is widely seen as a litmus test for turning decades of climate pledges into concrete action.
item.source:markdown: Talks at the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, were suspended on Thursday after a fire broke out in the venue, triggering evacuations that halted negotiations between more than 190 delegations. The summit was set to conclude Friday, and the disruption came at a critical moment as countries were locked in tense debates over fossil fuels and climate finance. The outcome of these talks is widely seen as a litmus test for turning decades of climate pledges into concrete action.

item.title: UNICEF: 20% of world’s children still trapped in extreme poverty
item.description: More than 19 per cent of children worldwide live in extreme poverty, surviving on under $3 a day, according to a new UNICEF report.
item.source:markdown: More than 19 per cent of children worldwide live in extreme poverty, surviving on under $3 a day, according to a new UNICEF report.

item.title: Unemployment rate hits highest level since 2021 - CSO
item.description: The unemployment rate for 15 to 65-year-olds reached 5.3% in the third quarter of this year, up 0.8 percentage points from 4.5% the same time in 2024.
item.source:markdown: The unemployment rate for 15 to 65-year-olds reached 5.3% in the third quarter of this year, up 0.8 percentage points from 4.5% the same time in 2024.

item.description: Three people have been charged by police investigating the alleged mishandling of cremated remains and alleged funeral plan fraud in Scotland.
item.source:markdown: Three people have been charged by police investigating the alleged mishandling of cremated remains and alleged funeral plan fraud in Scotland.

item.title: Delay in COVID-19 lockdowns in U.K. resulted in some 23,000 more deaths: public inquiry
item.description: Former British prime minister Boris Johnson oversaw a "toxic," "chaotic" and dithering response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a delay in locking the country down resulting in about 23,000 more deaths, a report by a public inquiry concluded on Thursday.

Former British prime minister Boris Johnson oversaw a "toxic," "chaotic" and dithering response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a delay in locking the country down resulting in about 23,000 more deaths, a report by a public inquiry concluded on Thursday.

item.title: Pope to Italian Bishops: Be prophets of peace in our fractured world
item.description:
During his visit on Thursday to the Italian hill town of Assisi, Pope Leo closes the 81st General Assembly of the Italian Bishops' Conference (CEI), and tells Italian Bishops to keep Christ at the center of all they do and to offer effective pastoral care, especially to families, young people, the elderly and the poor.

item.title: U.S. ambassador resents meddling in foreign electoral politics, but Trump doesn't seem to mind doing so
item.description: Pete Hoekstra accused Canada of interfering in electoral politics south in the U.S. Wednesday night at an event in Ottawa. item.title: Why the U.S. Justice Department and Congress may battle over redaction of Epstein files
item.description: When it comes to the Epstein files, there are solid reasons to withold certain information from the public, experts say. However, there are also grey areas that could cause disputes between lawmakers and the U.S. Department of Justice, and which could frustrate those seeking as much information as possible about the case.
item.source:markdown:
![Attorney General Pam Bondi speaks with reporters during a news conference at the Department of Justice, Wednesday, Nov. 19, 2025, in Washington. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/aa232cf5-363a-4911-863f-0ae748a215a2,1763598554373/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C245%2C4698%2C2642%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
When it comes to the Epstein files, there are solid reasons to withold certain information from the public, experts say. item.title: In the shadow of the Himalayas, this town is sinking, a casualty of the past and the present
item.description: Almost three years ago, hundreds of residents in Joshimath, India, were forced to leave after deep cracks appeared in the walls of some 800 homes because the ground was sinking around them. The town's location, climate change and heavy construction are being blamed.
item.source:markdown:
![Houses and other buildings are located at the bottom of a mountain range.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/3558d923-04f9-46d0-821c-3b469eaf4d93,1763588082114/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%281%2C0%2C4238%2C2383%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Almost three years ago, hundreds of residents in Joshimath, India, were forced to leave after deep cracks appeared in the walls of some 800 homes because the ground was sinking around them. The town's location, climate change and heavy construction are being blamed.

item.title: She lost 5 children during the war in Gaza — now she’s raising 36 grandkids in a tent
item.description: Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a black hijab sits in a dark tent as children play behind her. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b344396f-7c03-40c7-9b0a-b943e919b33f,1763611104438/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”

item.title: Listening to others out of love: Age is no barrier for religious sisters
item.description:

item.title: Pope highlights dignity of migrants, supports U.S. bishops' statement
item.description:
Answering questions from journalists in Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo XIV decries recent measures against migrants in the United States, and he calls for treating people “with humanity and dignity.” He also denounces the killings of Christians and Muslims in Nigeria and expresses hope for a ceasefire and dialogue in Ukraine, where "people are dying every day."

Read all

item.title: 1 of 25 students abducted in Nigeria found safe as search continues for missing girls
item.description: A schoolgirl who was abducted with 24 others from a dormitory in northwestern Nigeria has escaped and is safe, the school's principal told The Associated Press on Tuesday, as hunters joined security forces in the search for the missing students in forests close to the school.

item.title: Facebook owner Meta wins U.S. antitrust case, won't have to break off Instagram, WhatsApp

item.title: ‘Parasocial’ is Cambridge Dictionary's word of the year
item.description: If you felt more excited for Taylor Swift’s engagement announcement earlier this year than you did for your friend or family member’s, you might relate to Cambridge Dictionary’s word of 2025: "parasocial," which describes having a one-sided connection with someone you do not know, such as a celebrity, a fictional character or an AI chatbot.

item.title: Restarting the Economy: (Still) time to rest - the Jubilee Year as the world's 'Sabbath'
item.description:

item.title: Ghana’s Catholic Bishops outline pastoral priorities
item.description:
The Ghana Catholic Bishops’ Conference (GCBC) has concluded its 2025 annual plenary assembly held in the Diocese of Damongo, during which key pastoral priorities and national concerns for the coming years were outlined. The assembly took place from 7 to 14 November under the theme “A Synodal Church at the Service of Justice and Peace in Ghana.”

item.title: Dozens of people die in DRC mine accident

item.title: On Brazil’s Combu Island, chocolate makers hold clues to climate action
item.description: Combu Island – Ilha do Combu in Portuguese – rises like a wall of living green from Brazil’s Guamá River. It is a testament to centuries of shared existence between the forest and its riverside communities. Here, cupuaçu, taperebá, pupunha, araçá and cacao are more than fruits; they are threads in the fabric of local culture, livelihoods and identity.
item.source:markdown: Combu Island – Ilha do Combu in Portuguese – rises like a wall of living green from Brazil’s Guamá River. It is a testament to centuries of shared existence between the forest and its riverside communities. Here, cupuaçu, taperebá, pupunha, araçá and cacao are more than fruits; they are threads in the fabric of local culture, livelihoods and identity.

item.title: COP30 enters its final stretch: urgency, ambition, and voices from the streets
item.description: The last week of COP30 has begun in Belém with a palpable sense of urgency. Nothing less than charting a credible path to climate justice in a world running out of time.

item.title: Flower of Srebrenica takes root at the United Nations

item.title: Security Council LIVE: US hails ‘historic and constructive resolution’ on Gaza
item.description: The Security Council has passed a US-backed resolution which will establish an international force to restore order in Gaza, protect civilians and open the way for large-scale aid and rebuilding. There were 13 votes for, none against – while Russia and China abstained amid concerns that Russia might veto the text. US ambassador Mike Waltz thanked ambassadors, hailing it as an “historic and constructive resolution” which charts a new course for the Middle East. Follow live below, check out full meetings coverage here, and UN News app users, follow here.

item.title: Synod: Interim reports of Study Groups published
item.description:
Established by Pope Francis in March 2024, the Study Groups have delivered reports on the work carried out so far, starting from the conclusion of the Synod on Synodality. The deadline for delivering the final reports to Leo XIV has been set for 31 December. Among the topics covered are the digital mission, the role of women, ecumenism, polygamy, liturgy, the ministry of nuncios, and the selection of bishops.

item.title: Mexican government pursues second-shooter theory in 1994 political assassination that shook country
item.description: The March 23, 1994, death of Luis Donaldo Colosio, a reformer on the cusp of winning the Mexican presidency who promised a more just and democratic country, holds a space in the country's consciousness like the 1963 killing of President John F. item.description: A century-old Inuvialuit kayak once used for beluga and whale hunts, and 61 other cultural objects from First Nations, Métis and Inuit communities have long been held in Vatican Museums vaults. A century-old Inuvialuit kayak once used for beluga and whale hunts, and 61 other cultural objects from First Nations, Métis and Inuit communities have long been held in Vatican Museums vaults. item.title: 2025 CBC Massey Lectures: Alex Neve on renewing human rights in a fractured world
item.description: Universality was supposed to be the promise of human rights. Yet it’s been broken countless times. So how can we still fulfill it? Canadian human rights lawyer Alex Neve explores that question in this year's Massey Lectures.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Masa, 5, had been missing for almost 2 years. On Saturday, her family found her remains
item.description: Mu’ayyad Ajjour and his neighbour Mohamed Zaida have searched every day among the ruins of a building, hoping to find the remains of five-year-old Masa, Ajjour's cousin, so they can give her a proper burial. Her body is one of thousands thought to be buried in the debris of the war in Gaza. On Saturday, her remains were located and her body was taken to be buried.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Paris honours attack victims with vigils, lights, 10 years on
item.description: Paris is marking 10 years since the Islamic State attacks that killed 130 people after gunmen and suicide bombers targeted cafés, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall. People gathered at Place de la République for a candlelight vigil on the eve of the anniversary on Wednesday, and French President Emmanuel Macron and Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo were among those paying tribute at the attack sites on Thursday.
item.source:markdown:
![Eiffel Tower in Paris, France on the 10 year anniversary of the Paris Attacks.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/65aa76e4-d20d-48fd-bd49-559310570397,1763063640448/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C6874%2C3866%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Paris is marking 10 years since the Islamic State attacks that killed 130 people after gunmen and suicide bombers targeted cafés, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall. People gathered at Place de la République for a candlelight vigil on the eve of the anniversary on Wednesday, and French President Emmanuel Macron and Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo were among those paying tribute at the attack sites on Thursday.

Published by Libreria Editrice Vaticana and set to be released November 20, “La forza del Vangelo,” is an anthology of interventions and speeches by Pope Leo organized around key Christian themes.

item.title: A glimpse at the just-released “Leo from Chicago”
item.description:
Here’s a first look at the Vatican’s newly released documentary Leo from Chicago, which explores the roots of Pope Leo XIV and offers never-before-seen footage of Robert Francis Prevost in his native United States. The film features in-depth interviews with his brothers, Louis and John Prevost, and reveals new personal details — including what he looks forward to most on Thanksgiving, and how even as a boy he was able to turn 'an unruly little mob into friends.'

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: From Haiti to Ethiopia: voices of climate displacement at COP30
item.description: Floods, heatwaves, droughts and storms are forcing millions from their homes every year. Most never cross a border; they remain internally displaced yet uprooted all the same. But experts warn that in the not-so-distant future, entire nations could disappear beneath rising seas or become uninhabitable through drought.
item.source:markdown: Floods, heatwaves, droughts and storms are forcing millions from their homes every year. Most never cross a border; they remain internally displaced yet uprooted all the same. But experts warn that in the not-so-distant future, entire nations could disappear beneath rising seas or become uninhabitable through drought.

item.title: The hospital boats continuing Pope Francis' legacy in the Amazon
item.description:
On the sidelines of COP30 in Belém, Brazil, hospital boats are docked on the riverside, offering medical assistance to those most in need. The boats, inspired by Pope Francis, travel all along the Amazon River to tend to the needs to Indigenous communities and those who live along the river, far from cities. This is the testimony of Felipe, a volunteer doctor.

item.title: EU renews demand that Ukraine crack down on corruption in wake of major energy scandal
item.description: European Union officials warned Ukraine on Thursday that it must keep cracking down on graft in the wake of a major corruption scandal that could hurt the country's ability to attract financial help. item.source:markdown:

item.title: Trans woman in action over child's citizenship refusal

item.source:markdown: A UK trans woman, who used her frozen sperm to have a baby with her wife, has been granted permission to challenge a refusal by the State to grant Irish citizenship to the child on the basis that she is not the biological mother.

item.title: Indigenous activists storm UN climate summit in Brazil, demanding action
item.description: Security has been tightened at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil after Indigenous activists and other protesters burst through barriers at the venue on Tuesday night. Indigenous groups from across Latin America sent representatives with demands for an end to logging, mining, farming and fossil fuel extraction in the Amazon.
item.source:markdown:
![A tense confrontation between men wearing vibrant feathered headdresses and traditional attire. The scene is dynamic, conveying intensity and conflict.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/724a7425-46fe-43f4-9512-0587567b7390,1762964249668/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Security has been tightened at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil after Indigenous activists and other protesters burst through barriers at the venue on Tuesday night. Indigenous groups from across Latin America sent representatives with demands for an end to logging, mining, farming and fossil fuel extraction in the Amazon.

item.title: Pope at General Audience: Without fraternity, we cannot survive
item.description:
In his catechesis, Pope Leo highlights the importance of fraternity in our lives and describes it as something "deeply human". He explains that even though today's wars, tensions, and conflicts make fraternity seem difficult, without it, "we would not be able to survive, grow, or learn."

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In his catechesis, Pope Leo highlights the importance of fraternity in our lives and describes it as something "deeply human". He explains that even though today's wars, tensions, and conflicts make fraternity seem difficult, without it, "we would not be able to survive, grow, or learn."

item.title: French foreign minister, at G7 meeting in Canada, says U.S. boat strikes violate international law
item.description: During a G7 meeting in Ontario, France's foreign affairs minister said the deadly boat strikes in the Caribbean carried out by the United States since early September violate international law. Colombia, California's governor and the Washington Post also weighed in on the strikes on Tuesday — but Canada has been relatively silent on the U.S. actions.
item.source:markdown:
![Two men in suit and tie stand on either side of a woman in a maroon pant suit and scarf.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/07ef49d3-5a7e-45c2-8776-9c4eac951eed,1762952395487/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C180%2C8256%2C4644%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
During a G7 meeting in Ontario, France's foreign affairs minister said the deadly boat strikes in the Caribbean carried out by the United States since early September violate international law. Colombia, California's governor and the Washington Post also weighed in on the strikes on Tuesday — but Canada has been relatively silent on the U.S. actions.

item.description:
A letter from the Prefect of the Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith, Cardinal Victor Manuel Fernández, definitively confirms the negative opinion of the Bishop of Bayeux-Lisieux concerning supposed apparitions said to have occurred in Dozulé, France, in the 1970s.

item.title: Typhoon brings floods to Taiwan as thousands evacuated
item.description: Taiwan evacuated more than 8,300 people ahead of the arrival of a much weakened Typhoon Fung-wong that brought record downpours to the mountainous east coast and unleashed floods that rose neck-high in places.
item.source:markdown: Taiwan evacuated more than 8,300 people ahead of the arrival of a much weakened Typhoon Fung-wong that brought record downpours to the mountainous east coast and unleashed floods that rose neck-high in places.

item.title: U.S. tourism faces $5.7B US loss as Canadians continue to stay home
item.description: Many Canadians continue to boycott travel to the United States, and the U.S. economy is paying the price. A U.S. Travel Association report forecasts a 3.2 per cent decline in international tourism spending in the country for 2025, a loss of $5.7 billion US compared to the previous year.
item.source:markdown:
![Canadian and American flags fly near the Ambassador Bridge at the Canada-USA border crossing in Windsor, Ont. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/c7cb0f9e-b7e1-402b-afc2-16c1e473aec3,1762934027717/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C58%2C4500%2C2531%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Many Canadians continue to boycott travel to the United States, and the U.S. economy is paying the price. A U.S. Travel Association report forecasts a 3.2 per cent decline in international tourism spending in the country for 2025, a loss of $5.7 billion US compared to the previous year.

item.title: Swedish king’s visit highlights growing Canadian interest in Saab military aircraft
item.description: A few days before the federal budget was tabled, the CEO of Swedish industrial giant Saab flew to Ottawa to meet with the country's top bureaucrat, fuelling the sense a deal is brewing between the Canadian government and the military manufacturer. Now, the country's king, queen and a delegation of political and business leaders are set to visit from Nov. 18-20.

item.title: We have much to learn from our persecuted brothers and sisters in Africa
item.description:
Over the weekend, Pope Leo XIV speaking during the Saturday Jubilee Audience on 8 November 2025, in Saint Peter Square, reflected on the life of Blessed Isidore Bakanja, a young Congolese martyr. The testimony of Bakanja, “reminds us that we have much to learn from our persecuted brothers and sisters in Africa,” said Pope Leo XIV.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Over the weekend, Pope Leo XIV speaking during the Saturday Jubilee Audience on 8 November 2025, in Saint Peter Square, reflected on the life of Blessed Isidore Bakanja, a young Congolese martyr. The testimony of Bakanja, “reminds us that we have much to learn from our persecuted brothers and sisters in Africa,” said Pope Leo XIV.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa death toll rises to 45 in Jamaica, with 15 others still missing
item.description: The number of confirmed deaths from Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica rose to 45, with 15 other people missing, authorities said Tuesday. The death toll is expected to rise, with officials still trying to reach two towns that remain cut off since the catastrophic Category 5 storm made landfall in western Jamaica on Oct. 28.
item.source:markdown:
![People standing amid wreckage](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/684fb96c-51dd-428f-b465-26658ebaa992,1762888277420/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C237%2C4552%2C2560%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The number of confirmed deaths from Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica rose to 45, with 15 other people missing, authorities said Tuesday. The death toll is expected to rise, with officials still trying to reach two towns that remain cut off since the catastrophic Category 5 storm made landfall in western Jamaica on Oct. 28.

item.title: Consumer advocacy group urges OpenAI to pull video app Sora over privacy, misinformation concerns
item.description: Non-profit consumer advocacy group Public Citizen demanded in a Tuesday letter that OpenAI withdraw its video-generation software Sora 2 after the application sparked fears about the spread of misinformation and privacy violations.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: SIPTU warns of industrial unrest due to cost of living
item.description: The incoming General Secretary of the country's largest trade union, SIPTU, has warned of significant periods of industrial unrest because the cost of living crisis is "screwing workers".

item.title: Retired superintendent, four gardaí on trial in Limerick
item.description: The trial is under way at Limerick Circuit Court of a retired superintendent and four gardaí who are accused of perverting the course of justice by attempting to quash potential or pending road traffic offences on dates between October 2016 and September 2019.
item.source:markdown: The trial is under way at Limerick Circuit Court of a retired superintendent and four gardaí who are accused of perverting the course of justice by attempting to quash potential or pending road traffic offences on dates between October 2016 and September 2019.

item.title: Longest-ever U.S. government shutdown inches closer to ending after 8 Democrats cave
item.description: The U.S. Senate is on its way to ending the longest-ever U.S. government shutdown after a group of moderate Democrats agreed to proceed without a guaranteed extension of health-care subsidies, angering many in their caucus.
item.source:markdown:
![The image shows a close-up of the U.S. Capitol building's dome and facade with ornate columns and sculptures under a cloudy sky, conveying grandeur.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/fbd6ba07-5e7e-4c07-9b0e-4c380a223bc9,1762885149330/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C156%2C3000%2C1687%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The U.S. Senate is on its way to ending the longest-ever U.S. government shutdown after a group of moderate Democrats agreed to proceed without a guaranteed extension of health-care subsidies, angering many in their caucus.

item.title: Remote working a 'mistake', claims Denis O'Brien
item.description: Businessman Denis O'Brien has claimed there has been a "marked decline" in the efficiency of all parts of the Government due to remote working.
item.source:markdown: Businessman Denis O'Brien has claimed there has been a "marked decline" in the efficiency of all parts of the Government due to remote working.

item.title: ECJ upholds legality of EU's minimum wage directive
item.description: The European Court of Justice has upheld the legality of the EU's minimum wage directive following a legal challenge by Denmark to have the directive in its entirety annulled.
item.source:markdown: The European Court of Justice has upheld the legality of the EU's minimum wage directive following a legal challenge by Denmark to have the directive in its entirety annulled.

item.title: Cardinal Fernández at mysticism conference: ‘Spirit moves in varied ways’
item.description:
Attending a conference on “Mysticism, Mystical Phenomena, and Holiness” at the Pontifical Urban University in Rome, the Prefect of the Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith affirms the Holy Spirit's many different ways of manifesting God's presence throughout Church history.
